images.caption: Figure 1:The 3-3-1 Mixture of Agents (MoA) architecture and the deceptive agents within. Agents in the first layer provide a reference to the agents in the next layer, which generates a new set of references based on them. The aggregator synthesizes the final response. Two deceptive agents are illustrated.

Figure 1:The 3-3-1 Mixture of Agents (MoA) architecture and the deceptive agents within. Agents in the first layer provide a reference to the agents in the next layer, which generates a new set of references based on them. The aggregator synthesizes the final response. Two deceptive agents are illustrated.

Figure 2:The impact of asingle deceptive agent (1 out of 7)in MoA.
On both datasets, a single deceptive agent causes
the performance metrics to plummet, erasing almost all the gains from having MoA (see Section5, Figures4&7).

Figure 3:Under partial information availability, a single opposer placed in the second layer of the 3-3-1 MoA causes a significant drop in accuracy. The aggregator is Mixtral-8x22B-Instruct-v0.1, and the opposer is ignoring references from the previous layer.

Figure 3:Under partial information availability, a single opposer placed in the second layer of the 3-3-1 MoA causes a significant drop in accuracy. The aggregator is Mixtral-8x22B-Instruct-v0.1, and the opposer is ignoring references from the previous layer.

Figure 4:Accuracy of the 3-3-1 MoA with a varying percentage of deceptive agents. Weaker aggregators are more vulnerable, though the difference between the 70 billion and 405 billion Llama-3.1-Instruct models is less significant. Opposers result in a significantly stronger attack than promoters for all aggregator strengths.

Figure 6:Accuracy for the 3-3-1 MoA as the number of deceptive agents in the network increases. In the partial information setting, each agent receives a unique, mutually exclusive sub-passage, forcing them to rely on provided references. The distribution of the passage across agents further increases MoAâ€™s vulnerability.

Figure 7:LC WR of the 3-3-1 MoA under partial information availability decreases to below baseline levels when placing a single powerful deceptive agent in the second layer. The aggregator is Llama-3.1-70B-Instruct.

Figure 8:LC WR of a 3-3-1 MoA with a single deceptive agent on AlpacaEval 2.0. We vary the strength of the final aggregator. While the benefit of MoA diminishes with increasing aggregator size, the effect of one deceptive agent stays unchanged.
